1.event: The Marriage Protection Act (Act 98-500) is passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Amendment 774 to the Alabama constitution is passed 81-19%, forbidding marriage or other "unions replicating marriage".
The Supreme Court refused to put same-sex marriages on hold and they began, although same-sex couples had difficulties getting marriage licenses in many counties.
The Alabama Supreme Court ordered judges to stop issuing same-sex marriage licenses, in apparent defiance of the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

2.event: In Brause v. Bureau of Vital Statistics, an Alaska Superior Judge ruled choosing a marital partner is a fundamental right that cannot be denied by the state without a compelling reason, and asked for further hearings to determine whether a compelling state interest to ban same-sex marriage.
Amendment to the Alaska Constitution is passed 68-32% (Article 1, Section 25), forbidding same-sex marriage.
The Supreme Court rejected a request to block same-sex marriage in the state, and same-sex marriages will begin, although the state has said they will appeal.

4.event: A marriage license was given to two Phoenix men. The state legislature then passed an emergency bill banning same-sex marriage.
A federal judge the state's ban on same-sex marriage. The ruling was not put on hold and the state has said it will not appeal.

5.event: The state legislature passed HB1004 (modifying Arkansas Code 9-11-109), banning same-sex marriage.
Amendment 83 to the Arkansas Constitution was passed 75-25%, forbidding same-sex marriage or legal status "which is identical or substantially similar to marital status".

A state judge struck down the state's same-sex marriage ban and did not issue a stay, and same-sex marriages began. The state's attorney general intends to appeal and will ask for a stay. The Arkansas Supreme Court issued a stay which halted same-sex marriages in the state.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

6.event: Assembly Bill 26 of 1999 passed, granting domestic partners some rights.
Domestic partner rights were expanded to most of the rights that married couples have.
The California Supreme Court ruled In re Marriage Cases that the previous statutory same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional.
Proposition 8 passed 52-48%, amending the state constitution to forbid same-sex marriage.

The Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in Hollingsworth v. Perry that the sponsors of Proposition 8 did not have standing to appeal the case, thus reverting to the District Court ruling that same-sex marriage is legal in California. Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

8.event: After Clela Rorex, the county clerk of Boulder County, allowed six same-sex couples to wed, a law was quickly pushed through to forbid same-sex marriage.
Amendment 43 to the Colorado constitution passed 55-45%, forbidding same-sex marriage. In the same election, Referendum I was defeated 53-47%, which would have allowed same-sex domestic partnerships.
House Bill 1260 takes effect, allowing two unmarried adults to become each other's designated beneficiary.
The same-sex civil unions bill takes effect.
After the Supreme Court let the 10th Circuit's ruling stand, the state began giving out marriage licenses.

9.event: The state legislature passed Public Act No. 05-10, establishing same-sex civil unions.
The Connecticut supreme court ruled in Kerrigan v. Commissioner of Public Health that the constitution protects the right of same-sex marriage.

10.event: The Marriage Protection Act added a statute forbidding same-sex marriage.
The civil unions bill takes effect.

11.event: The Health Benefits Expansion Act was finally funded by Congress after 10 years, thus allowing domestic partnerships in the District of Columbia.

In the previous December, the City Council voted 11-2 in favor of legalizing same-sex marriage. The mayor signed the bill, and it will go into effect in Spring 2010 after Congress' mandatory review period has expired unless Congress acts. The bill legalizing same-sex marriage then took effect.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

12.event: The Defense of Marriage law passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
The Florida Marriage Amendment to the Florida constitution passed 62-38%, forbidding same-sex marriage and possibly same-sex civil unions.

In July 2014, Aa county judge struck down the state's same-sex marriage ban. While the judge ordered that same-sex marriages could begin the next week, the attorney general announced that she would appeal, which caused a stay to be issued. The stay was finally lifted and same-sex marriages began.

13.event: The Georgia General Assembly enacted Title 19, Section 19-3-3.1, forbidding same-sex marriage.
An act amending the Georgia constitution to forbid same-sex marriage and possibly civil unions passed 76-24%.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

15.event: Reciprocal beneficiary relationships were created in Hawaii, allowing couples who cannot legally get married (including same-sex couples) to have a limited number of rights and benefits.
Senate Bill 232 takes effect, allowing civil unions.

16.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage and possibly civil unions.
Idaho Amendment 2 passed 63-37%, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions in the state constitution.
The Supreme Court allowed same-sex marriages to continue.

17.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
The Illinois Religious Freedom Protection and Civil Unions Act takes effect, allowing same-sex civil unions.

In November, the State House of Representatives passed a same-sex marriage bill by 61-54, followed by the State Senate passing the same-sex marriage bill by 32-21. Governor Pat Quinn signed the same-sex marriage bill. Same-sex marriages finally take effect.

18.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.

A federal judge struck down the state's same-sex marriage ban and instructed state agencies to start issuing marriage licenses. A federal appeals court put the ruling allowing same-sex marriage on hold pending an appeal.
The Supreme Court let the 7th Circuit's ruling stand, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

19.event: 1998 Ia H.F. 382 passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
A ruling in the Varnum v. Brien case allowed same-sex marriage for a short time in Polk County in Iowa.
The judge then ordered a stay of his ruling pending the county's appeal. As of March 2009, the case is before the Iowa Supreme Court.
The Iowa Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the law forbidding same-sex marriage was unconstitutional.

20.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Article 15, Section 16 of the Kansas Constitution passed 70-30%, forbidding same-sex marriage.

A US District Court judge granted an injunction stopping Kansas from enforcing its same-sex marriage ban, although the ruling is on hold until November 11. The state has said they will appeal. The Supreme Court rejected a request to put the ruling on hold, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

21.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Constitutional Amendment 1 passed 75-25%, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

22.event: The Marriage Recognition Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Constitutional Amendment 1 passed 78-22%, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
District Judge William Morvant of Baton Rouge struck down the constitutional amendment, finding that it violated a provision of the state constitution requiring amendments to only cover one subject.
The Louisiana Supreme Court overruled the district judge and reinstated Constitutional Amendment 1.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

23.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Domestic partnerships were established in Maine, providing some rights to same-sex couples.
Maine Question 1, allowing same-sex marriage, takes effect on December 29, 2012.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

24.event: The Maryland Statutes Family Law forbids same-sex marriage.
The Civil Marriage Protection Act takes effect, allowing same-sex marriage.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

25.event: The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health that the state must allow same-sex marriage within 180 days.

26.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Michigan State Proposal - 04-2 passed 59-41%, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions or any sort of domestic partnership benefits.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

27.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
The same-sex marriage bill, passed by the Minnesota State Senate by a vote of 37-30 in May 2013 and signed by governor Mark Dayton, takes effect.

28.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.

Mississippi Amendment 1 passed 86-14%, amending the Mississippi Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage. A US District Judge struck down the state's ban on same-sex marriage, although the ruling is on hold for two weeks in case the state wishes to appeal.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

29.event: 2001 Mo. H.B. 157 passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Missouri Constitutional Amendment 2 passed 71-29%, forbidding same-sex marriage.
A circuit court judge ruled that the state's ban on same-sex marriage is unconstitutional. The state has said they will appeal, but will not seek a stay.

30.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
Montana Initiative 96 passed 67-33%, amending the Montana Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage.
A US District Judge ruled that the 9th Circuit's ruling applied to Montana as well, and allowed same-sex marriages to begin immediately. The state has said it will appeal the decision.

31.event: Nebraska Initiative Measure 416 passed 70-30%, amending the Nebraska Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
A federal judge in Omaha struck down the ban on same-sex marriage and civil unions in the case Citizens for Equal Protection v. Bruning.
The 8th Circuit Court of Appeals reinstates the ban on same-sex marriage and civil unions as a result of the case Citizens for Equal Protection v. Bruning.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

32.event: Nevada Question 2 passed 67-33%, amending the Nevada Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage. (this was done in two consecutive elections, as required by Nevada law)
SB283 took effect, allowing domestic partner benefits to all couples.
Same-sex marriages began in the state.

33.event: Per HB 437, civil unions are given out to same-sex couples.
HB 73 took effect, allowing same-sex marriage.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

34.event: The Civil Union Act passed the New Jersey Legislature and was signed by the governor, allowing for same-sex civil unions.
New Jersey governor Chris Christie dropped the state's appeal of Garden State Equality, et al. v. Dow, et al., which makes same-sex marriage legal in the state.

35.event: The New Mexico Supreme Court ruled in that same-sex marriage is allowed in the state.

36.event: The same-sex marriage bill takes effect.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

37.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Amendment 1 passed 61-39%, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
After a ruling from a US District Judge, same-sex marriages began in the state.

38.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
North Dakota Constitutional Measure 1 passed 73-27%, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

39.event: HB 272 passed, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
Ohio State Issue 1 passed 62-38%, amending the Ohio State Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

40.event: The Marriage Recognition Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Oklahoma State Question 711 passed 76-24%, amending the Oklahoma Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court let the 10th Circuit's ruling stand, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

41.event: Oregon Ballot Measure 36 passed 57-43%, amending the Oregon Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage.
The bill took effect, allowing for same-sex domestic partnerships.
A federal judge struck down the ban on same-sex marriage and allowed counties to begin issuing marriage licenses immediately.

42.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
A federal judge struck down the state's same-sex marriage ban and allowed same-sex marriages to begin immediately. Governor Tom Corbett said he will not appeal the ruling.

44.event: Over objections of some same-sex marriage advocacy groups, Governor Lincoln Chafee signed the civil unions bill, which takes effect retroactively on July 1.

In May, the State House passed the same-sex marriage bill, and Governor Lincoln Chafee signed it into law, making Rhode Island the last state in New England to allow same-sex marriage. The law will go into effect on August 1. Same-sex marriages begin.

45.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
South Carolina Amendment 1 passed 78-22%, amending the South Carolina Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court denied a motion to put the previous ruling on hold, and same-sex marriages began.

46.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
South Dakota Amendment C passed 52-48%, amending the South Dakota Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

47.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Tennessee Amendment 1 passed 81-19%, amending the Tennessee Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

48.event: Acts 1997, 75th Leg., ch. 7, Sec. 1, eff. April 17, 1997 passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Acts 2003, 78th Leg., ch. 124, Sec. 1, eff. Sept. 1, 2003 passed, forbidding same-sex marriage or civil unions.
Texas Proposition 2 passed 76-24%, amending the Texas Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The Supreme Court ruled in Obergefell v. Hodges that same-sex marriage was legal in all 50 states.

49.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
Utah Constitutional Amendment 3 passed 66-34%, amending the Utah Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
A federal judge struck down the ban on same-sex marriages. The state is expected to appeal the decision and it is likely the decision will be stayed pending appeal.
The governor put same-sex marriages on hold pending the state's appeal.
The Supreme Court let the 10th Circuit's ruling stand, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

50.event: 1999, No. 91 (Adj. Sess.), § 25 passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
The Vermont Civil union law went into effect, allowing for same-sex civil unions.
The same-sex marriage bill takes effect.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

51.event: The Code of Virginia was amended to forbid same-sex marriage.
The Code of Virginia was amended to forbid same-sex civil unions as well.
The Marshall-Newman Amendment passed 57-43%, amending the Virginia Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions or any private contracts that would have the same effect.
The Supreme Court let the 4th Circuit's ruling stand, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

53.event: The Defense of Marriage Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
The state legislature passed a domestic partnership law, providing some benefits of marriage to same-sex couples.

Referendum 71 passed 53-47%, giving all benefits of marriage to same-sex couples. It was the first time in the US that voters approved a state-wide ballot measure that extended LGBT relationship rights.
Washington Referendum 74 takes effect, allowing same-sex marriage.
Same-sex marriages in the state became recognized by the federal government after the Supreme Court decision in United States v. Windsor.

54.event: The Marriage Protection Act passed, forbidding same-sex marriage.
The Supreme Court let the 4th Circuit's ruling stand, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

55.event: The Wisconsin Family Code forbids same-sex marriage.
Wisconsin Referendum 1 passed 59-41%, amending the Wisconsin Constitution to forbid same-sex marriage or civil unions.
The state budget takes effect, allowing very limited domestic partnerships.
The Supreme Court let the 7th Circuit's ruling stand, and same-sex marriages began in the state.

56.event: The Wyoming Domestic Relations Code forbids same-sex marriage. The date when this code was drafted and approved was not known.

The Supreme Court let the 10th Circuit's ruling stand, although same-sex marriages had not begun yet. A US District Judge overturned the state's same-sex marriage ban, although the ruling was put on hold while the state decides whether to appeal. Same-sex marriages will begin on October 23 or immediately if the state does not appeal. The state said it would not appeal, and same-sex marriages began.
